articles.heading: Proven facts. Is the economy doing well or badly?
articles.subheading: Apocalyptic forecasts about GDP or the labor market have been denied by reality and by data from Eurostat, Bank of Spain, OECD and INE
articles.text: In 1992, the United States faced an election campaign fuelled by military victories in the Gulf War. With that war capital under his belt, President George Bush thought he would win easily at the polls. However, the deteriorating economy was more decisive than the war and tipped the balance in favour of Democratic candidate Bill Clinton. His campaign manager, James Carville, relied on a slogan - 'it's the economy, stupid' - to defeat Bush on the basis of mortgage rates, employment data or the cost of living. Carville's slogan has become the most widely used example worldwide to explain the importance of the economy in any election campaign....
